segments.text: of working with 23 sabbatical and other postdoctoral level people from throughout many different countries and different states and and that that meant that that we had people coming in working normally on their own support or at least mostly on their own support and
And they had maturity and motivation.
And that made research a lot more fun.
We could have research group meetings with people who had worked in South Africa or worked in Saudi Arabia or worked in Indiana.
And that, I think, is the synergism of putting research and teaching together and development of these books, all told, close to 3,000 pages of published books.
that I've edited and written a significant part of, but certainly not a major part of.
As you began here, did anybody, whether you invited them to or not, did anybody give you any advice, any directions?
Morris Bloodworth was a very
I'd say friendly and open type of administrator.
I remember talking to him about the fact that, well, there was always a need for more money.
And I said, what about writing proposals?
And he said, well, that's the icing on the cake.
And he encouraged it.
But being a large estate as it is and as many problems that we have,
and fortunately have had reasonable support within the state, and trying to grow as we have, well, that wasn't such a big issue.
But as far as him telling me I should work on this or that, he was not very inclined to do that.
I think that he brought things to our attention by these meetings that we had, whether they were at Beaumont or Lubbock or somewhere else.
And these people all around us, occasionally Godfrey would come in with some new observation from the field that was stimulating.
And of course, when we went
out in the state we always looked at the local crops and the local soils and this gave us quite a bit of stimulus and exposure.
Was there any area of the state that you soon realized needed more than its proportional share of attention?
It seemed like that Overton
had a high priority at that time.
They had the deep, sandy soils there, but the soil test, chemical soil test, didn't jibe with the response of the plants.
And they asked me to come and look at the situation with them and had a grad student
that had just started his master's degree with me named Frank Hans.
And Frank wanted to go and look at that as possible thesis work.
So he went up and worked one summer and I remember taking a truck and a trailer with a backhoe on it and driving to Overton to dig that soil pit.
I don't know if I would do that today or not, but it went very well and I was really impressed when I got the backhoe to going in the right direction and got the pit dug about two meters deep
And there stood the superintendent of the station and other staff out.
I think it was the first time they had seen that soil two feet, two meters deep.
And what we could see right away that the chemical soil test tested the upper
foot of soil or less and the roots of the plant were extending down rather through the full two meters of Bermuda grass roots so deeply.
And we had a chemical study and mineralogy study underway but we learned a whole lot that one during that day just from seeing the plant and the soil as they interacted.
So that was one of our first, and then we published that work, and Frank Hans is now on our faculty, as you probably are aware.
He later got his doctor's degree with Dr. Hosner, and he worked at Texas Tech for a few years before he joined our faculty here.
Beaumont was in the rice producing area, or it is, and they had some problems with the brooding of rice in that submerged environment.
Iron toxicity can occur, and that, they,
they were wrestling with.
So I had a student from China, actually from Taiwan, Tsai Chin Chin.
Tsai came without any money, but he wanted to do a master's degree.
And he painted houses to make his living.
I couldn't support him at that point.
And he finally got a job at Beaumont in the summertime.
And then he really began to get into a master's thesis on that.
And what we found was that the rice plant pumps the oxygen down into the root zone and oxidizes the iron and it precipitates and forms a red boundary around the roots of the rice.
Well, one of the questions was, is that a protective boundary, a layer, and is that preventing the phosphate from getting to the root and things like that?
That didn't prove to be the case, but in the second phase of that work, we did find that those varieties of rice that pumped the most oxygen down were the best varieties.
And they, in other words, controlled the iron by oxidizing it and precipitating it.
So that was very stimulating work.
And that stimulated me to think about what was happening when iron went from solution to solid phase in a matter of weeks in the field, a very short span of time.
In 1982, I went to Arizona State and did a sabbatical.
And that is the national facility supported by National Science Foundation for high resolution electron microscopy.
And there were no soils people there and very few geology types.
It was a work group of engineers, physicists, chemists, and a few geologists.
But they had this built around this electron microscopy facility.

So for that year, I learned to use an advanced electron microscope, and when I came back and looked at some of those materials from Beaumont, I could, through that instrument, identify the phases better than we'd ever been able to do it before and characterize them.
And some were what we call amorphous or non-crystalline,
or close to that, and then some were rather well crystalline.
So those things just supplemented each other growing out of that study down there.
And that work has created quite a lot of attention because it was so challenging.
We had probably three different students or postdocs to attempt
to identify those poorly ordered phases that formed in the soil and around the roots of rice.
And the fellow who eventually solved it was a student who came as a postdoctoral to us, and he's originally from a very remote part of the world.
and what you might think would be an unpretentious kind of person, but he turned out to be quite a scholar.
D.C. Golden is his name, and he's from Sri Lanka, and he's now employed as a part of the Mars program in NASA, at the Johnson Pace Flight Center in Houston.
As you were getting underway here, were there any subjects or topics that by some fashion you understood that those were kind of to be left alone, don't waste time on them or don't do that?
I really can't recall being pushed around at all.
I think we always had so many possibilities.
And now, I would say perhaps one way of looking at that question, there are so many problems that, one, they have to be approached with such delicacy sometimes that we learn

fairly early on to be rather careful about attacking a problem without giving it quite a lot of thought because the conditions, like around the rice roots, many times we made some steps forward, but we were not able to go completely to understanding the system more thoroughly until we got different instrumentation.
When I got back from sabbatical,
We had a head of our electron microscopy center, Carl Duffner.
He was hired after I returned from Arizona, and fortunately for he and I, he was trained as Arizona in the same institute where I did my sabbatical.
That's purely a coincidence.
He was an Aggie, and he had gotten his early training here in chemistry.
and he went out there for his doctoral work.
Well, he and I chose the microscope, the 2010 microscope that we have and that I've used for the last 18 years or longer, and he used, too.
So those things complemented our work here and sort of came together.
And now, of course, we're undergoing a new evolutionary stage in the Micro Center.
trying to expand it further.
And in fact, Maya serving on the chairman of the committee of the Users Committee for Electron Microscopes through many years was a very stimulating experience.
And I'd say I got dealing with Abe Clearfield in chemistry and others through that medium that has been a distinct asset
throughout my studies here.
In your first months, semesters, years, what did you learn?
There were any kind of general guidelines for the department?
How were you expected to dress?
Were there any things in your spare time you weren't supposed to do?
Any organizations to join or not join?
I always felt rather free.
We always had a
an unwritten dress code, I think.
I don't have on a necktie today.
In those days, I think I always had on a necktie.
And I had that shaken a bit.
We had a special meeting at Stanford University at the Synchrotron facility they have out there some years ago.
And I found that when I went there, I was perhaps the only person on the campus that had on a necktie.

Well, I thought the people at Stanford were doing very well without the neckties, and it's pretty warm in Stanford and pretty warm here, and maybe we could get along just as well without them so much here.
But actually the only relaxing that's ever been given in terms of instruction is in the College of Agriculture,
and life sciences, Friday is considered to be an informal, more informal day.
And if we choose to wear blue jeans, then we can wear them then and things like that.
About when did that begin?
Not very many years ago.
I would say something like five years ago.
Was there a formal, was that written down?
That was written down.
It was, okay.
I think that definitely came under our present dean.
I think I remember Ed Heiler's memo saying that with good discretion, you may dress informally on Friday.
In your first years, normally what were the hours
that it was expected you were to be on campus?
Get here by what time and stay at least until?
Well, the College of Agriculture has, so far as I know, has always been rather eight to five-ish.
And I've always enjoyed my work, and I've always been here at least that long, and usually a bit longer, and do a significant amount of work on the weekends.
And the advent of the computer has really extended work.
And I know a few years ago, I tell students occasionally in jest that
The main discovery I've made in recent years, and I was at that point trying to get one of these books out, the main discovery I've made has been Saturday and Sunday.
Because when you undertake these books and you're working with dozens of authors from around the world, it just takes a lot more time than one would probably anticipate.
In those early days, Ridge Park,
Parked right beside the building, yes, yes.
And normally was there a departmental, was there a coffee pot in your building?
Where did you get?
Oh, that always seemed to take care of itself.
There always seemed to be a coffee pot nearby.
Oddly enough, coffee without pie doesn't go very well for me, so I've never been an ardent coffee drinker.
When I was at Auburn, it was very structured informally.
People gathered twice a day, I think, to drink coffee.
Certainly they gathered in the morning.
But I was an oddity.
I just couldn't be comfortable.
When I drank that coffee, that took up too much of my day.
So I was a little bit rebellious.
In those years, where did you lunch?
I've been a brown bag person so long that I have a hard time remembering when I wasn't a brown bag person.
Did you eat your brown bag lunch in your office by yourself or with a group?
Well, I usually eat it with the group today and I, well, I say, no, that's, you have to, one has to think about that in context of the building.
And we really didn't have
Honestly, I can't remember exactly where we ate our lunch when I was in the old state chemist building.
Was there a group that ate together?
There has been a group that gathered from time to time throughout my career here, and some even played bridge in the noon hour.
I didn't happen to fit very well into that.
But we do a lot of visiting during the noon hour, yes.
We have in the past, and we do even today.
And some of it is across departmental lines, but mostly it's within the department and mostly among soil scientists.
Did people smoke in their office in those days?
I'm sure that some did.
I grew up in a tobacco patch in western Kentucky, and I had a distinct prejudice against tobacco and all of its products.
So I've always stayed on the fringes.
But yes, we did, unfortunately, have to smell somebody smoke occasionally.
But that wasn't much of a problem.
You know, when people realized that I didn't smoke, they were rather courteous about not smoking around me.
All right.
talking about your initial impressions.
You got here in the summer.
Yes.
And that fall, what was your impression then when the students came and football and all the traditions?
Describe that for a newcomer from Kentucky.
Well, it was a bit overwhelming, and I guess we were mostly stimulated by it, and we did participate in it to a significant extent.
I don't think it was as well developed in those days as it is now as far as the, you know, since Rudder Center has been built, our social atmosphere has been enhanced enormously.
And we enjoy that and appreciate that.
In those days, I remember gathering in that old Guyon Hall, I guess it was, and hearing President Rutter read a speech to us.
And I might say, one of the highlights of not coming to Texas A&M that I always remember was that whenever Dr. Rutter, not Dr. Rutter, but President Rutter, had a banquet for the new faculty,
And he said very deliberately, if you see anything that you want to do at Texas A&M and there's anybody standing in your way and you still want to pursue this, you come and tell me about it, please.
All right, your impression, describe your whole impression of Earl Rudder.
Well, he was big in more than physical form to me.
We had several, Martha and I had several fortunate interactions with the Rutters.
The first Sunday I think we were in church at A&M United Methodist Church, we chose a position in the pews that looked like it was sort of
a little bit toward the front, next to the center aisle, and we sat there.
And then later, someone told us, said, did you know that President and Mrs. Rutter normally sit at that position?
Well, we moved a bit.
but not too far.
And so we continued to sit somewhere in that vicinity.
And I would say on numerous occasions we would look down the bench or across the bench to see Mrs. Rutter and President Rutter.
And we always held him and Mrs. Rutter in very high regard.
because they were so nice to us.
And even today, whenever Mrs.
Rudder sees my wife, she calls her by her first name.
And when we were in France, we went to the Normandy coast and saw the site where our president had led a military assault on that.
How much did you as a faculty member in those early years, how much presence did Mr.
Rudder have?
Did you see him much?
I'd say, to me, he was very visible.
Of course, I saw him.
I drove by his house every day going home, and I saw him very frequently on Sunday.
He wasn't, I would say, so very visible on the campus.
Otherwise, because I have
rather imagine he was awfully busy in his own office.
What image do you think that he had, the faculty had of him?
Well, I think that all of us who came in under his, like I did while he was the president, I think we held him in very high regard.
And a bit in awe because we knew that he did not have an academic background, but
Yet he had high visions, and that's what put him in a high place as far as I was concerned.
He was not impeded by what many other people guarded so much.
Then come on down in administrative order, the Vice President of Academic Affairs, as we then called it, when you got here.
Was Wayne Hall still in that role?
I think so.
I remember that name, yes.
And then Zener.
Who was Dean of Agriculture?
Oh.
Was it Patterson or, oh, ta-ta-ta-ta-ta-ta.
I see.
Before, well, it would have been Kunkel.
Kunkel was dean during much of my tenure here.
Describe him as dean, his manner, his style.
What I liked about Kunkel was that every year when we had our January planning meeting for the Experiment Station personnel, which we still have today, he was very scholarly.
in his presentations, and that I appreciated.
It seemed to me that he held a high standard in the science and the scholarliness with which he presented subject matter.
I always thought he had a good vocabulary and presented himself well.
Now, of course,
I had quite a lot of interaction with Neville Clark, and I thought he was a good, strong leader.
Neville was?
Director of the Experiment Station.
There were several other support people over there, Vic Schimber and so on, that we had some interaction with, but the dean and the Experiment Station director were the two major ones.
And I would say that as I think about a university now, looking back versus as an employee and growing up professionally, it seems to me that
the administration is a lot more separate when beyond the department level than I would have expected it to be.
And thus, the faculty, I think, tends to expect a bit of interaction and perhaps a bit of counsel, although they're not looking for exactly instruction.

As I view it now, the dean and the director of the Experiment Station, and more now than before, the department head, is so heavily committed to other directions that he doesn't have much time to look at the faculty and interact with them.
We are evaluated every year, and I think that's good.
When that first initiated, it was like other evaluations.
We looked at it with a bit of suspicion, but it turns out to be a good thing for everybody.
And I think that's one of the stronger administrative aspects of the way the College of Agriculture is run.
I would say if, on the other hand, we would like to have the whole administration evaluated,
as we are evaluated, and we would like for that to be available in some summary form so we would see
Faculty don't complain very much in my area.
I couldn't register very many things.

That one few complaints I've ever heard and I heard time and time again is that we would like to know what the administration does because it seems like through the years we've seen an increase in number of administrators and we've seen a decline in number of faculty and a number of support staff.
And we would like to think that in the best interest of everyone, we should be able to evaluate the efficiency of all parties.
And that should be rather freely open information.
Again, back to the early days,

Were there any hints or anything about whether anyone could, their social activities, that one is not to ever be seen drinking public, one is never to ever play poker, one is never to go to this place?
Were there any guidelines that you understood from anywhere?
Not that I'm aware of.
You know, that could be that some were, but I wasn't.
All right, now, this is way, way, way back.
I asked that of Fred Benson a long time ago.
And he said when they first got here, you never, and they were living on campus, you were, yeah, this is an editorial note.
This is a conversation with Fred Benson who later was a great dean of engineering.
He said that when he and his wife first got here, it was made very clear to them that you never served alcoholic beverage unless you had the shades and the blinds closed.

and that if you played poker for money, you also closed the blinds, and that under no circumstances did you ever serve alcoholic beverage if there were any students present, that whether it was a faculty student group, there was to be no alcohol ever served, and that he said it was clearly understood that one was expected to go to worship services pretty regularly.
Didn't matter what your denomination, whether Protestant, Catholic, Jewish, but you were to go.
All right, but now, end of the note.
In those early years, were you ever teased by not being an Aggie or not being a native Texan?
Did that seem to matter at all?
No, I really never felt that way.
In fact, I can tell you sort of personally that I always felt that I was particularly
appreciated because I chose to come to Texas A&M.
And I can't tell you that that was by my peers especially, and in fact by some that were just friends that I had met here locally who were on the faculty in other departments.
And so I would say quite the contrary.
I think that the faculty here was very receptive and they didn't
They didn't try to bring me into line with all the Aggie trappings particularly.
As you met your first classes and had your first graduate students, how did Aggie students compare with Auburn and Wildcat students at UK?

This has been a real exciting place to teach and it's kind of hard to generalize because the course that I've taught and taught consistently soil mineralogy to graduate students was taken by civil engineers, oceanographers, geologists, soil scientists, occasional ag engineers, and occasionally rain science.
and those are students with rather diverse backgrounds and it's difficult and this is a foundation course in soil science so I usually get students who just arrived from Taiwan or from
from Houston or wherever, early in their programs.
And this would be as graduate students?
Yes, as graduate students, but as beginning, early on graduate students.
And so sometimes they had particular linguistic difficulty, in a few cases certainly.
And the ones in civil engineering have a very different background from those from soil science or...
